title: UBS and Larry Summers keep Afterpay interesting
text:
Last week, executive director David Hancock (finally) resigned, unlocking his shares in the company worth $123.1 million (at Thursday’s closing price, if he still even owns them).

The very next day, Afterpay announced that former US Treasury secretary Larry Summers “will join its (new) US Advisory Board.” Can Anthony Eisen and his cast of spinners dance or what?! Subleasing the appearance of good governance from some Clinton-era fossil without one iota of fiduciary responsibility. What a joke. Was Jimmy Cayne too busy playing bridge? “I was impressed with the company being principled,” Summers told this newspaper. That and his new (invisible) stock options.

Remember, this is the guy who helped broker the removal of barriers between US retail and investment banking. “This historic legislation,” he said of the Glass-Steagall Act’s repeal in 1999, “will better enable American companies to compete in the new economy.” And 10 years later, to blow it sky high.

Then, as Harvard president, Summers resigned after suggesting “there are issues of intrinsic aptitude” explaining why women were under-represented in the senior ranks of science and engineering. Has Afterpay’s chairman Elana Rubin considered the kind of message Summers’ bought endorsement would send the company’s female software engineers (if they had any)? Or did that consideration simply not pass through (what Larry considers) Rubin's inferior lady-brain?

Finally, on Wednesday, Tom Beadle and Jonathan Mott of UBS became the first banking and credit analysts to initiate research on Afterpay, giving it a 12-month price target of $17.25, 52.8 per cent south of Tuesday’s $36.56 closing price.

Some would say that’s generous! Their modelling relies on Afterpay having 5 per cent of US adults spending $2800 a year on the platform by 2030 and for its revenue to hold at 4 per cent of total transaction value right out to 2025. But Klarna, its much larger rival in that market, already has a rack rate for merchants of 2.3 per cent. If Afterpay can maintain its income at 4 per cent, we’ll throw a garden party for Nick Molnar at Camp David.

Afterpay has since fallen to $31.98, down 12.5 per cent. Motion sickness, anyone? And AUSTRAC's only just getting warmed up. Hey, regardless of where you’re sitting, this is easily the best ride in the park.
description: Subleasing the appearance of good governance from some Clinton-era fossil, can Anthony Eisen and his cast of spinners dance or what?!
